reviews.review_msg: She is nice on the outside and responds to emails quickly however she blatantly favours some student over others. Her marking is very strict and I have never seen so many people finish a midterm only to get a mark significantly lower than they had expected. The paper also had unclear guidelines and was marked very poorly. Would not recommend her

Took a seminar with Maike this term and really enjoyed it. She is very engaged and is always available to meet face to face to discuss personal issues and assignments. Strong emphasis on participation.

Stay away. Gets mad when you take notes on a guest lecturer then proceeds to ask difficult and detailed exam questions about what they said. Yaps more about Taylor Swift and her political ideologies than actual course content. Final exam also expected you to have outside knowledge about current events not related to the course.

Genuinely the worst experience I've ever had with any Crim professor. We had no idea what we were being marked on, and the feedback we received genuinely gave us no insight on how to improve. Our final had nothing to do with the course content, and essentially set us up for failure.

Pam is a kind and approachable professor. It's apparent that she's passionate about what she teaches, which is nice to see. However, I would not take a course with her again. The course structure was disorganized, the grading criteria was unclear, and she was travelling so often that our lectures were on Zoom, and we had too many guest lecturers.
Someone needs to find a better side hustle...
Save yourself sometime and just do not take a class with her.

Messy professor and always unclear about expectations. "Do not panic about the prep test it will all be from the slides" and then she includes multiple questions that were never mentioned in lecture, and a question about a video we watched during a lecture when she had technical difficulties and showed it to us through her LAPTOP with no volume...
Just avoid..........
MESSIEST PROFESSOR AT SFU BY FAR. DISORGANIZED SCATTERED AND ALWAYS LATE. She postpones every lecture and is NEVER at SFU ever. Why teach a class and travel the entire time???

Pam's class could have been better this semester. Most classes were online due to her busy schedule with Innocence Canada. She seemed preoccupied/scattered, but assignments were easy and guest lectures from exonerees were moving. The final felt disconnected from class content. Overall, the class was an easy A, but it could have been more engaging.

Pam Pam Pam, why do you make students literally do your job for you?!??? Like, she literally told us at the start of the semester that she needed to redo the Innocence Canada website (for her other job) AND THEN LITERALLY MADE THAT OUR FINAL. Creativity is marked for the problems & recommendations we chose too. Like, how does that help US learn.

Pam is extremely unorganized and almost always starts class late. She encourages not to take notes because she will provide you with a summary or discuss the content in depth but she never does. Lectures are tedious as she easily gets distracted and talks about nothing for hours on end. Did not learn a single thing throughout the semester. AVOID.

Pam was very unorganized throughout the class. She moved almost every single lecture online but made the tutorials in person which was very inconvenient. Further, her final exam was not very reflective of what we have been learning throughout the year. She mainly wanted us to redo her website and do her job for her.

Final exam was absolute nonsense. I swear to god she just gets students to give her ideas so she can use it to improve her website as Director of Innocence Canada. Baffling. A three hour final that was mindnumbingly pointless to end an absolutely pointless 4 months. The guest speakers are the only thing of value in her class. AVOID.

To put it simply, the only thing that remotely teaches you anything in this class is the guest speaker lectures - anytime Pam talks it is just pointlessly asking questions of the class that we can't answer because we haven't learned anything yet and a lot of self-centered babble about herself. Terrible class. Pointless assignments. Just no.

Took 103 and she wasn't bad, the lectures were good then. 438 not so great. Due to her schedule, classes were basically mostly online which wasn't a problem, but having to travel for a 50 min tutorial was very unfair. Lectures were disorganized. Only good thing was the extensions she offered. Marks fairly easy. easy workload for upper div.

Assignments/memos are straight to the point. Her assignments allow some flexibility, incorporating practical, real-world thinking skills rather than traditional assignments. She can get distracted easily in lectures, but overall not unbearable. Passionate with students, often gives extensions. Considerably light workload for a 400-level course.

She is very unorganized, tries too hard to be quirky and cool and against the "status quo" in school but I really don't feel like I learned anything in her class. Found her irritating. But her class was pretty easy, you won't have to do an essay and you will barely have to take down notes. But you will have to sit through hours of pointlessness.

Pam is a great professor! Has a real passion for wrongful convictions and making sure students are engaged and learning. Take her classes and stay after class for office hours, she's super cool and understanding.

Throughout my undergrad, I have never had a professor who genuinely cares about their students the way Pam does. She gives thorough feedback and offers practical assignments that allow you to think critically. Amidst the pandemic, I appreciated how engaging this course was with in-class discussion and guest lecturers. She is an amazing professor!

Pam is the most caring and inspiring instructor Ive had at SFU. You can easily tell that not only does she care deeply about the topic (wrongful convictions), but she cares so much about her students too. She really goes above and beyond for her students. Her teaching style is very engaging and frequently involves current events and discussion.

Pam is a creative, caring and considerate professor. She teaches unique topics, so her students actually learn something new each lecture. Pam encourages her students to display critical thinking through fun and opinion-based assignments. I looked forward to her class each week because she made the lectures an experience!

I usually love classes with her but this semester, it has been so boring and I am not sure why. We are reading 60+ pages in readings and there are about 3-5 per module. I find it super long and tedious.

Trouble keeping up with readings and lectures. If you miss something, forget it because she doesn't repeat - even the big ideas - and the lectures are not recorded or accessible online at all. Didn't adapt well to COVID times, had multiple online lectures but you still need to go to tutorials, so you still need to be on campus.

A great lecturer! Helene is engaging and ensures to take her time when lecturing so no student falls behind when note-taking. Grading scheme is a little bit nit picky in regard to getting a full 100% in essay/IRAC questions on exams (understandably so). But if you did well in CRIM 330, CRIM 438 with Helene would be an amazing course for you.
